entry.title: Getting started with Prompt Templating in SAP Generative AI Hub: Principles and Implementation
entry.content:
In enterprise AI, prompts are everything. A well-crafted prompt can unlock context-aware, high-quality responses, while a poorly structured one can lead to irrelevant or inconsistent outputs. But scaling prompt engineering across business scenarios requires more than creativity - it needs structure, governance, and reusability.
This is where prompt templating in the SAP Generative AI Hub comes in.

In this blog, we‚Äôll first explore the principles and lifecycle of prompt templating and then walk through an example implementation using Generative AI Hub SDK in python.

What is Prompt Templating?

Prompt templating is the practice of designing prompts with reusable structures where certain elements are parameterized. Instead of hardcoding values, you define placeholders that get filled dynamically at runtime

For example:

 

Here, {{complaint_text}} is a placeholder. At runtime, the system replaces it with the actual input, making the template reusable across multiple use cases.

Why Prompt Templating Matters

In enterprises, scaling prompts without templating can be chaotic. Here‚Äôs why templating is essential:

1. Reusability - One template, infinite use cases.
2. Consistency - Standardized responses across users, teams, and apps.
3. Governance - Store, version, and audit prompts in a registry.
4. Flexibility - Easily adapt prompts to different scenarios without rewriting logic.

Before we move on the principles let‚Äôs look at a high-level flow of the lifecycle of prompt templating.

The lifecycle of prompt templating can be summarized in five simple steps:

  1. Design a template with placeholders (e.g., {{customer_name}}, {{text}}).
  2. Fill placeholders with runtime values.
  3. Send the finalized prompt to the LLM.
  4. Capture and return the model response.

 

 

Key Principles of Effective Prompt Templating

When designing prompt templates, keep these guiding principles in mind:

1. Parameterize Inputs

Identify which parts of your prompt will change and make them variables.

  • Example: {{customer_name}}, {{invoice_number}}
  • Tip: Use meaningful variable names so the intent is always clear.
 2. Follow Instructional Patterns

LLMs perform best when instructions are clear, explicit, and structured.

  • State the task directly (e.g., ‚ÄúSummarize in 3 bullet points‚Äù).
  • Provide examples if needed to guide the model‚Äôs behavior.
3. Plan for Error Handling

Not all inputs will be perfect. Templates should anticipate edge cases.

  • Define fallback instructions (e.g., ‚ÄúIf information is missing, respond with ‚ÄòInsufficient details‚Äô.‚Äù).
  • Validate inputs before filling them into prompts.

Implementation of Prompt templating using in Python using SAP generative AI Hub

Before we begin, make sure you have:

  • Access to SAP AI Core.
  • SAP Generative AI Hub SDK installed (Python) .
  • A registered LLM deployment available in your AI Core tenant.

 

Steps

  • Open your Jupyter/VS Code notebook.
  • Import orchestration models from the SDK.
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.message import SystemMessage, UserMessage
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.template import Template, TemplateValue
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.llm import LLM
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.config import OrchestrationConfig
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.service import OrchestrationService
  • Define a template for your task (translation, summarization, classification, etc.).
template = Template(
    messages=[
        SystemMessage("You are a helpful customer support assistant."),
        UserMessage("Summarize this complaint into a polite response: {{?complaint_text}}")
    ]
)
  • Pick the LLM (already deployed in AI Core).
llm = LLM(name="gpt-4o", version="latest", parameters={"max_tokens": 100})
  • Configure orchestration.
config = OrchestrationConfig(template=template, llm=llm)
orchestration_service = OrchestrationService(config=config)

print(result.orchestration_result.choices[0].message.content)
  • Run inference by passing dynamic inputs.
  • Get structured, predictable outputs from the model.

Further resources:

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core/sap-ai-core-service-guide/use-prompt-template
  • https://btp-ai-bp.docs.sap/docs/technical-view/generative-ai/plain/prompt-templating

entry.title: AI-driven, Joule-enabled Warehouse Resource & Operations Management for SAP EWM on S/4 HANA 2023
entry.content:
It is a topic in every warehouse: Supervisors and Warehouse Operations Managers would like to see their planned workload for the day and see in real-time whether shipping times will be met. If shipping times are in jeopardy, the warehouse system is then expected to evaluate if an optimized resource allocation could pro-actively solve any potential delays. When a more optimal usage of the available resources is found, resources should automatically be directed to the critical areas. Being able to take action proactively is of the essence, because we do not want to only take action when we are already in delay.

The following is an example of an AI-driven, Joule enabled Application that can accomplish the above outlined requirements and activities supported by AI. The Application leverages the embedded AI in the EWM Private Cloud Edition S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 release and the Joule Studio available in SAP Build.

 

 

The Architecture of the Application looks as follows:

 

AI-based Warehouse Workload Visibility

In the current version of the Application, the expected workloads of picking and packing operations are calculated leveraging the embedded AI capabilities in SAP EWM, which are then displayed in the UI5 Application (see in the example below):

It is also clearly visible in which Activity Area the workload is currently exceeding the planned Resource capacity.

The Application then further allows a manual simulation of adding or removing Resources to evaluate the impact in a given activity area. 

The fully "automatic rebalancing" function evaluates whether it is possible to optimize the resource allocation to the different areas, considering the allowed resource types in an Activity Area.

If an optimized resource allocation is possible, the warehouse operations manager, can accept these changes and the resources will be reassigned in the EWM system so that they will receive workload to execute from the new area.

Joule-enabled with custom EWM Joule Skills

Further more the current version of the Application provides Joule support for Warehouse Operations Management with the following Joule Skills:

- Joule Skill 1: Current Workload Analysis: Provide a comprehensive analysis of the current workload associated with picking and packing operations, considering the current resource allocation across different warehouse areas, as well as dependent scheduling of packing activities.
- Joule Skill 2: Provide Optimized Resource Allocation: Simulate an optimal workforce allocation strategy to mitigate bottlenecks and criticalities within the warehouse operations, to avoid shipping delays.
- Joule Skill 3: Accept Optimized Resource Allocation: Accept the optimization results and reassign the resources in EWM to the new areas.   

Coming soon an AI Agent will be introduce that autonomously orchestrates workforce allocation (monitored by the supervisor).

For more Information on this Application & AI functionality please contact SAP Services (EWMServices@sap.com).

entry.title: Empowering Healthcare Innovation with SAP Generative AI Hub
entry.content:
Unlocking Healthcare's Future: With SAP Generative AI Hub, you can start your Business AI journey, education and experience at your hospital or research organization by implementing Large-Language-Models (LLM) based use cases at low risk and low invest while having a portfolio of leading models of choice.

There is no healthcare without innovation and AI is paramount for this, at least since AI left the laboratories back at Davos in 2022. Hospitals and research institutions need modern and state of the art tools to enhance patient care, streamline processes, and accelerate research. This is where the SAP Generative AI Hub, built on the robust foundation of SAP AI Core, emerges not just as a tool, but as a strategic partner. It e.g., provides a secure, scalable, and intelligent bridge for hospitals and research institutions to harness the power of Large Language Models (LLMs) responsibly and effectively.

An Elegant and Strategic Entry into AI, Without the Lock-in

For many healthcare CIOs, committing to a single LLM provider feels like a high stakes bet. The SAP Generative AI Hub masterfully resolves this dilemma. It functions as an abstraction layer, providing a single, consistent interface to a multitude of LLMs. This ‚Äòfuture-proofs‚Äô your AI strategy, allowing you to adopt superior, medically-trained models as they emerge and with minimal disruption. This agility allows organizations to start their AI journey with confidence, knowing they are not tied to a single technology but are instead investing in a flexible, evolving ecosystem.

The Vision: An Intelligent Data Layer to Empower Clinicians

The true revolution, however, lies beyond simply accessing an AI model. The ultimate vision is one where AI tools operate upon a unified enterprise and clinical data layer. Imagine e.g., a foundational data platform that intelligently consolidates information from disparate systems into a single, cohesive, longitudinal patient record.

It is upon this unified foundation that the SAP Generative AI Hub operates at its full potential. It becomes the intelligent reasoning engine that could help e.g., clinicians to interact with a patient's complete journey through natural language. Instead of spending hours piecing together a patient's history, a clinician can ask complex questions that were previously impossible to answer efficiently:

  • "Summarize this patient's full clinical history from the lab systems, highlighting any imaging findings relevant to their current complaint."
  • "Analyze the latest pathology report in the context of the patient's genomic profile and suggest relevant clinical trials."
  • "Compare the progression of this patient's tumor markers against anonymized data from similar patient cohorts and flag any statistical anomalies."

This shifts the clinician's role from a data retriever to a data interpreter and strategic decision-maker. The AI handles the assembly and synthesis of information, freeing the clinician to focus on what truly matters: complex diagnosis, treatment planning, and patient care.

Elevating Prompt Engineering from an Art to a Science with AI Launchpad

To enable such powerful interaction, the AI must be guided with precision by normal users like a clinician without e.g., relying on or demanding limited expert IT staff. This is supported by the SAP AI Launchpad that transforms prompt engineering from an ad-hoc activity into a managed, enterprise-grade discipline.

  • Seamless Integration into clinical workflows: The prompts and models managed in AI Launchpad can be seamlessly integrated into applications like the EMR. With a single click, a clinician e.g., can trigger a pre-approved prompt to generate a referral letter, drawing on data from across the unified layer without ever leaving their primary workflow.
  • A Centralized Playground for Experimentation: The Launchpad provides a sandbox environment to test prompts across different LLMs. A clinical researcher can test prompts to see which model can most accurately synthesize a patient's history from the unified data layer for a cohort study.
  • Enterprise-Grade Lifecycle Management for Prompts: A well-crafted prompt is a valuable asset. The AI Launchpad allows you to version, test, and deploy them across the organization, ensuring that if a clinical guideline changes, all relevant prompts can be updated instantly for consistent, high-quality output.
  • Fostering Collaboration and Standardization: The AI Launchpad creates a central ‚Äòprompt library‚Äô, breaking down departmental silos. A prompt perfected by the radiology department to analyze imaging reports could be adapted by the oncology department, accelerating innovation across the institution.

A Fortress of Security for Consolidated Health Information

The consolidation of such comprehensive patient data onto a single logical layer elevates the importance of an uncompromising security architecture. The idea of sending this sensitive data to external AI services is a non-starter. The SAP Generative AI Hub is designed as a secure proxy that mitigates these risks.

By routing all interactions through the hub, which runs on the secure SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), hospitals gain a central point of control. It allows for the consistent application of security policies, access controls, and data anonymization techniques before any data leaves the organization's secure environment. This creates a trusted framework where the immense power of generative AI can be leveraged without compromising on patient privacy or regulatory compliance.

One Contract, a World of Possibilities

Navigating the procurement and legal complexities of multiple AI vendor contracts is a significant drain on resources. The SAP Generative AI Hub eliminates this by offering access to a diverse portfolio of leading LLMs through a single commercial agreement with SAP. This grants your institution the agility to use the best model for understanding clinical terminology and another for analyzing operational data, all without being bogged down by procurement cycles.

Conclusion

The SAP Generative AI Hub is more than a platform; it is a critical component of a visionary strategy to unlock the true potential of integrated clinical data. By providing secure, flexible access to the world's most advanced AI models, it lays the groundwork for a future where clinicians are empowered with complete, synthesized information at the point of care. It‚Äôs time to move beyond the hype and begin building a more intelligent, efficient, and personalized healthcare system for everyone.

 

Sources for Inspiration

  • Unleashing the Power of SAP AI Launchpad & SAP AI Core: Create Your First AI Application
  • SAP AI Launchpad Community Page
  • SAP AI Core is All You Need

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 1
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

Agentic AI Chatbots in the Enterprise Context

Enterprises today need more than a chatbot that simply provides guidelines or answers FAQs. In real business contexts, users expect AI systems that can actually take action ‚Äî querying databases for insights, drafting or sending emails, and orchestrating multi-step workflows. This growing demand has led to the rise of agentic AI chatbots, which combine the familiarity of a conversational interface with the power to execute enterprise-scale tasks. While frameworks such as LlamaIndex, AutoGPT, and LangGraph enable orchestration, enterprises need robust deployment, seamless integration, and governance to run them at scale.

This blog series will walk through that journey step by step. We‚Äôll start by building a custom agent backend, then deploy it on SAP AI Core, and finally make it directly consumable from Joule Studio ‚Äî enabling business users to interact with the agent through a natural conversational interface inside Joule.

üöÄ To make the process easier to follow, we‚Äôve divided the content into three parts:

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend 
  • Part 2 ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core 
  • Part 3 ‚Äî Integrating the Agent into Joule Studio 

By the end of this series, you will have a clear, reproducible path from

  1. Custom AI agent code in GitHub
  2. Scalable deployment on AI Core
  3. Business-ready conversational interface through Joule Studio.

 

Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend

In this first post, we focus on the backend logic of the custom agentic chatbot. This backend is implemented with Flask and exposes REST API endpoints that support both one-shot and multi-step interactions. While one-shot calls return only the final answer, the multi-step design allows the system to expose the agent‚Äôs reasoning process step by step, improving interpretability and transparency.

Custom AI Agent Chatbot Backend Capabilities 

For demonstration purposes, the backend is designed to handle common enterprise tasks such as:

  • Structured Data Access ‚Äì Query SAP HANA Database to support reporting, analytics, and decision-making.
  • Vector-based Retrieval ‚Äì Search SAP HANA Vector DB to enable advanced RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) use cases.
  • Enterprise Communication ‚Äì Manage enterprise emails (drafting, sending, or forwarding messages) through integration with existing systems.
  • External Information Retrieval ‚Äì Fetch context from real-world services (e.g., weather updates, web search results) to enrich responses.

API Endpoint Design for Agent Orchestration

In our implementation, we adopted LangGraph as the orchestration framework. Since the agent dynamically generates a plan first, and then builds a LangGraph structure based on that plan, it was natural to split the API into multiple steps:

/v2/plan ‚Üí /v2/action-graph ‚Üí /v2/start-execution ‚Üí /v2/continue-execution

This is just one way to design it. With a different orchestration style, you might merge steps into a single /chat endpoint or a simpler two step flow. 

Endpoint Summary:

MethodPathSummaryRequest Body
GET/v2/healthHealth check-
POST/v2/planStep 1. Generate planconversation_id, message
POST/v2/action-graphStep 2. Create action graphconversation_id
POST/v2/start-executionStep 3. Start Executionconversation_id
POST/v2/continue-executionStep 4. Complete Execution conversation_id
POST/v2/chatOne-shot chatconversation_id, message

These endpoints reflect how the workflow is divided into steps in our design. To make it more concrete, here's a minimal Flask example showing how each endpoint might look in practice.

Example Flask Code:

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import uuid

app = Flask(__name__)

# Health check
@app.route('/v2/health', methods=['GET'])
def health_check():
    return jsonify({"status": "healthy"})

# Step 1: Plan generation
@app.route('/v2/plan', methods=['POST'])
def generate_plan():
    """
    Example route for generating a plan.
    - Replace the stub logic with your own planner (LLM, LangGraph, rule-based, etc.).
    - Store the plan into session or external state manager if needed.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    message = data.get('message','')
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id') or f"session-{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"

    if not message:
        return jsonify({'error': 'Message is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Call planning logic here

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "plan_generated",
                    "content": "<example plan object>"})

# Step 2: Action graph creation
@app.route('/v2/action-graph', methods=['POST'])
def generate_action_graph():
    """
    Example route for generating an action graph.
    - Replace with your real plan ‚Üí graph transformation.
    - Retrieve the plan from session or agent manager before creating the graph.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get planning state > Implement graph creation logic here

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "action_graph_generated",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# Step 3: Start execution
@app.route('/v2/start-execution', methods=['POST'])
def start_execution():
    """
    Example route for starting execution.
    - Replace with logic to execute the first node of the action graph.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get action graph > execute the first node of the graph

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_started",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# Step 4: Continue execution
@app.route('/v2/continue-execution', methods=['POST'])
def continue_execution():
    """
    Example route for continuing execution.
    - Replace with logic to execute remaining nodes and return the final response.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get action graph > execute remaining nodes and return final response

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_complete",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# One-shot chat
@app.route('/v2/chat', methods=['POST'])
def chat():
    """
    Example route for one-shot chat.
    - Replace with your pipeline that runs plan ‚Üí graph ‚Üí execution in one step.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    message = data.get('message', '')
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')  # use conversation_id as session_id

    # TODO: Process agent pipeline here all at once

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_complete",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host="0.0.0.0", port=5000)

‚ö†Ô∏è  Note: this is only an example. Replace the TODO sections with your own orchestration logic.

With this backend in place, we now have a clear foundation for orchesting multi-step agent workflows, from plan generation to action execution, all exposed via REST APIs.

 

üëâ  In the next part, we'll take this custom agent backend and deploy it on SAP AI Core: packaging the Flask service into a Docker container, creating a ServingTemplate, and exposing it as a production-ready endpoint.

entry.title: Partners unveil generative AI applications to solve real-time industry challenges with SAP and AWS
entry.content:
AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation Program

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP and Amazon Web Services (AWS) unveiled the AI co-innovation program aimed at assisting partners in developing Generative AI applications to address business challenges. This program integrates advanced GenAI technologies from SAP with Generative AI Services from AWS, complemented by SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Data, to facilitate customer implementation journeys.

As a pivotal advancement in the SAP AI co-innovation program, AWS and SAP have established a new cohort in collaboration with SAP‚Äôs well-established Hack2Build initiative. This cohort provides support for the development, testing, and deployment of industry-specific applications. Partners are encouraged to develop industry-focused solutions utilizing AWS generative AI tools and services from Amazon Bedrock, including large language models (LLMs) such as Amazon Nova and Anthropic Claude within AI Foundation on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). This enables partners to swiftly develop and deploy AI applications tailored to their customers‚Äô SAP workloads.

Hack2Build

Hack2Build Cohort- September 2025 with AWS

 The new cohort of Hack2Build, an initiative of Partner Excellence Center, SAP Partner Ecosystem Success in collaboration with AI Partner Product Management, SAP Business AI and Amazon Web Services, brought together AI expertise from SAP and AWS and architects to expedite the development of partner Generative AI applications within a seven-day timeframe. Ten partners were selected across various regions as part of this initiative. Experts from SAP and AWS provided support and guidance to the selected ten partners on the chosen use cases. The hack phase commenced on September 22nd and concluded with an impressive demo jam on September 30th.

Partners selected for Hack2Build Cohort with AWS and SAP - September 2025

Hack2Build Cohort: üéâ Winners

 In this blog post, we will delve into the generative AI solutions developed by the winning partners. These solutions leverage the capabilities of Generative AI Hub, a component of SAP AI Core, a service within the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). By accessing various Large Language Models (LLMs) on Amazon Web Services (AWS) through the Amazon Bedrock platform, the partners have harnessed the power of generative AI to create innovative solutions.Hack2Build Cohort 2025-Winners' Podium- AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation

üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏èüßëüèª‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è Judges

 On September 30, 2025, a distinguished panel of senior leaders from SAP and AWS convened to select three winners from the demo jam.

  • Kamal Arora, Director of Solutions Architecture and AI Innovation at AWS USA
  • Marc-Oliver Klein, Vice President and Head of Partner Product Management and Strategic AI Development Partnerships at SAP SE
  • Stefan Wellner, Vice President of Technology Alliances, Platform and Incubation Partnerships at SAP Business AI Ecosystem at SAP SE
  • Tom Adams, Director of Global Business Consulting and Advisory Partners at AWS USA 

 ü•á Winner: Atos

Atos presented an AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis solution that addresses external vulnerabilities in supply chains, particularly unforeseen disruptions. The solution integrates real-time hazard data with SAP metrics to enhance operational resilience. It also integrates SAP BTP services UI5 and CAP applications with AWS AI services, including the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model on Amazon Bedrock. Key features demonstrated include real-time disruption data collection and automated supplier prioritization integrated with SAP S/4HANA systems.

AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis by Atos

ü•à1st Runner up - Capgemini

Capgemini demonstrated a GTS smart check solution that seamlessly integrates with SAP GTS and SAP S/4HANA. This solution effectively addresses challenges in import processing, where manual document handling and compliance checks result in delays. The solution significantly reduces import processing time, thereby saving substantial hours annually. This is achieved through the automation of data extraction and comparison from multiple document sources using the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model from Amazon Bedrock.

Capgemini's GTS Smart Check Solution

ü•â2nd Runner up - NTT Data

NTT Data unveiled its Voice Control ERP Assistant, a collaborative solution designed to alleviate the challenges associated with accessing ERP systems on the shop floor. This innovative solution addresses the inherent difficulties faced by workers in navigating unfamiliar ERP systems without disrupting their workflow. By seamlessly integrating SAPUI5 and HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Vector Engine, Generative AI Hub within SAP BTP Services, and Anthropic Claude LLM from Amazon Bedrock, including Amazon Polly for voice interaction, the solution enables hands-free access to ERP data and documentation. Specifically targeting the manufacturing industry, the solution demonstrated substantial business value by enhancing task focus and mitigating employee turnover.

Voice Controlled ERP Assistant by NTT Data

üëèüèº Finalists

We thank all the finalist teams who successfully demonstrated the innovations to the panel of judges, as a part of this Hack2Build cohort.

FinalistsMinimal Viable Product demonstrated
AccentureNavi , a smart delivery scheduling solution focusing on the supply chain's inefficiencies in developing countries
CognizantAsset Unitization AI, addresses manual asset unitization challenges in asset-intensive industries
DeloitteRelationship Management Agent, automates the processing of email queries related to supplier and vendor management
IBMSustainable Buddy, addresses sustainability challenges for better operational transparency and efficiency in Oil & Gas
LTIMindtreeFieldSense.ai, enhances SAP Service and Asset Manager to streamline field service operations, improve safety, and ensure compliance in Utilities and Manufacturing
Phoenix ConsultingAutomated Supplier Invoice Processing, addresses high manual effort and error rates in accounts payable ,supporting Arabic characters and Hindu numerals
Tech MahindraImprove PO extraction  and Sales Order creation process, easing the process of extracting data from challenging invoice formats like blurry or multilingual images.

üôè  Special Thanks

We extend our appreciation to the many AWS and SAP experts , who coached the partners to successfully develop their solutions during this Hack2Build initiative.

‚òû  Next Phase

We anticipate that all participating partners will now proceed to finalize their comprehensive solution within a timeframe of 6 to 8 weeks. SAP and AWS will actively engage with all participating partners to provide support throughout their development process in the upcoming weeks, ensuring that their innovations are prepared for customer deployment.

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (3)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing the skill on Work Zone

In the previous part, we designed a CustomAgent Skill that links your AI Core backend actions and defines how Joule interprets user inputs. Now, it‚Äôs time to test it live, right inside Joule Chat Interface, and finally share it with your organization‚Äôs via Work Zone, so that others can access your agent.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Test your Skill in Joule Chat Interface
  • share the Skill to Work Zone for organization-wide access

 

1. Test the Skill in Joule Chat interface

Once your Skill is released and deployed to the environment, it becomes available inside the Joule Chat interface.

Step 1. Launch Joule Chat Interface

Go to Control Tower ‚Üí select correct Environment ‚Üí More ‚Üí Joule ‚Üí Launch

This opens the Joule Chat interface for that specific environment.

Step 2. Start Conversation

You can start chatting naturally by sending any message, Joule will automatically detect the appropriate Skill based on your setup.

 

In this example, we'll start the conversation using an activation phrase (e.g., /CustomAgent) to trigger the Skill explicitly based on how we set from skill description in this post. This approach helps ensure the correct Skill is activated during testing.

Example. Triggering the Skill and maintaining a continuous agentic flow

The example below illustrate how the CustomAgent Skill is triggered and how the agentic workflow executes step by step. Here, the backend queries SAP HANA Cloud to retrieve real-time stock data before generating a natural-language summary response.

Joule detects the message and routes it to the CustomAgent Skill (triggered by /CustomAgent). This skill is linked to your backend endpoint deployed on SAP AI Core, which handles the reasoning and multi-step action execution. 

 

üîç  How the Agentic Flow Executes

  1. Planner Stage (/v2/plan) : The backend receives the request and generates a plan. Example from the chat,
    • Generate SQL query to check current stock level for 'Wireless Mouse' product.
    • Execute the generated SQL query to get current stock level.
    • Provide a clear response about the available stock quantity.
  2. Action Graph Creation (/v2/action-graph) : The agent converts the plan into series of executable steps in LangGraph.
  3. Execution Stage (/v2/start-execution) : The actions are executed in order (querying stock, formatting a reply, etc.).
  4. Response Delivery (/v2/continue-execution) : The final message is sent back to Joule, which displays the result in the chat.

Each stage is visible in the conversation window as we designed Joule Skill in the previous post, allowing user to trace the full reasoning process step by step.

 

‚ôæ  Maintaining a Continuous Conversation

To maintain continuity between messages, the system uses a unique converation_id that is shared between Joule and your backend. 

When a message is sent to the Joule, Joule parses the conversation_id from the user input.

On the backend side (AI Core), it either:

  • uses an existing conversation_id provide by the user and parsed by Joule ‚Äî to continue an ongoing conversation
  • generates a new one if nothing is provided ‚Äî to start a new conversation   

This design ensures that every conversation session can be explicitly tracked and resumed. 

The example below show how the agent continues the same conversation seamlessly using the shared conversation_id.

 

Because Joule parsed and passed the same converstaion_id (session-b31e574a) from the previous turn, the backend recognized that the new message belonged to the same session. As a result, the agent was able to reference the previous HANA query result and compose a follow-up order email template ‚Äî without the user needing to restate any context.

 

üí¨  Extending the Flow to External Tools

In the next step, the same converstaion_id (session-b31e574a) was used again ‚Äî this time to send the previously composed order email through Gmail integration.

The following example shows how the same agentic flow extends beyond Joule to interact with an external tool like Gmail.

Here, the backend reused the prior plan and template ‚Äî demonstrating how multi-step reasoning, enterprise data retrieval, and third-party API execution can all occur within a single continuous conversation inside Joule.

 

2. Share the Skill to Work Zone

Once your Skill is tested and working as expected, you can share it to Work Zone so that other users in your organization can access it. This is done by sharing the Joule capabilities from your Control Tower > Environments.

  • Go to Control Tower ‚Üí Environments ‚Üí Select your Environment
  • Navigate to the Joule tab at the top
  • Click the gear icon (‚öôÔ∏è) next to your Joule environment

 

Now you can share your Skill with specific users or user groups in your organization.
This process is well explained in the following SAP Community post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build ‚Äì Part 4: Managing Access to Custom Joule Skills 

 

Wrapping Up the Series

With this final part, you‚Äôve completed the Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio series.

You now have:

  • A Flask-based agentic backend running on SAP AI Core
  • A Skill in Joule Studio that connects to it through Actions
  • A live conversational interface integrated into SAP Work Zone

Through this setup, you‚Äôve built an enterprise-ready agentic chatbot ‚Äî capable of reasoning over enterprise data, executing dynamic multi-step actions, and integrating securely with external tools inside your organization.

This concludes the series on building an end-to-end Custom Agentic Chatbot. We hope this walkthrough helps you design, deploy, and scale your own AI agent workflows with confidence using SAP AI Core and Joule Studio. üöÄ

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 2 (1)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)

 
Now that we have our custom agentic chatbot backend code (Part 1), the next step is to make it enterprise-ready by deploying it to SAP AI Core. This ensures the agent runs in a scalable, secure, and managed environment, and provides a REST inference endpoint that can be consumed by Joule Studio.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Have an AI Core workspace, resource group, and secrets set up
  • Build and push your chatbot backends as a Docker image
  • Define a ServingTemplate YAML file for deployment

 

What is AI Core?

SAP AI Core is a managed service that lets you deploy and operate AI workloads at scale. Instead of running your model on a single machine, AI Core provides containerized deployments, auto-scaling, and secure integration with the rest of SAP BTP. This is what transforms a local prototype into a service that enterprises can reliably consume.

 

How to Deploy in AI Core?

Before jumping into the detailed setup, note that all configuration for AI Core, including workspace, resource group, Git repositories, and secrets, can be conveniently managed through the SAP AI Launchpad. In this guide, we'll demonstrate the Launchpad-based setup since it's the most intuitive starting point. 

 

1. Preparing AI Core Environment

Before deploying, we first configure the AI Core environment. Think of this step as laying the foundation before placing your container on top.

Step 1. Create a Workspace

A workspace is a logical container to organize your AI projects.

Step 2. Create a Resource Group

Resource groups help organize deployments and credentials. They also provide isolation so you can manage access by project or environment.

 

Step 3. Add Git Repositories

Connect your GitHub repository so AI Core can fetch deployment configuration (e.g., ServingTemplate YAML)

 

Step 4. Create an Application

Define the application that will consume AI Core resources.

 

Step 5. Create Generic Secrets

Store sensitive credentials (API keys, DB credentials, OAuth tokens) securely instead of hardcoding or push to shared repository. These secrets will later be referenced inside the YAML envFrom section.

 ‚ö†Ô∏è Secrets must be in JSON format and Base64 encoded

Example:

{ 
 "LANGCHAIN_API_KEY": "YOUR_LANGCHAIN_API_KEY_ENCODED",
 "WEATHER_API_KEY": "YOUR_WEATHER_API_KEY_ENCODED",
 "GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID": "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID_ENCODED",
 "GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET":"YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET_ENCODED" 
}
 

2. Containerization

Next, package your Flask backend into a Docker image. This step ensures your code runs the same way across environments.

Step 1. Create a Docker file

FROM python:3.11 

# Copies file from your Local system to path in Docker image 
COPY AgentBuilder.py . 
COPY Utils.py . 
COPY app.py . 
COPY requirements.txt . 
COPY prompt_lib.py . 

# Installs dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt 

CMD ["gunicorn","--worker-class", "eventlet", "-w", "1", "--bind", "0.0.0.0:5000", "--timeout", "1200", "--keep-alive", "2","--max-requests", "1000", "--preload-app", "app:app"]

Step 2. Build & Push the Image

docker build -t <registry>/<repo>/agentic-chatbot:<version> . 
docker push <registry>/<repo>/agentic-chatbot:<version>

 

3. Define the Serving Template

In SAP AI Core, deployments are defined by a ServingTemplate YAML file. This tells AI Core how to run your container, which port to expose, and how to allocate resources.
Example:

At this stage, your environment and container are ready for deployment.

üëâIn the next section, we'll actually deploy the container, test the live endpoint, and confirm that it's ready to connect with Joule Studio.

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 2 (2)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)

 
In this continuation of Part 2 (1), we'll focus on putting everything together:
  • Register the ServingTemplate in AI Core
  • Create a Configuration and Deployment
  • Test the live REST endpoint

 

Step 1. Register the ServingTemplate

Push the YAML file to your connected Git repository. SAP AI Core will automatically detect it and register it as:

  • Scenario: high-level use case
  • Executable: specific deployable artifact

 

Step 2. Create Configuration

Link the YAML-defined Executable to runtime parameters.

  • Configuration Name: any unique name (e.g., agent-chat-config)
  • Scenario: auto-populated from scenarios.ai.sap.com/name
  • Version: as defined in ai.sap.com/version
  • Executable: auto-registered from executables.ai.sap.com/name

Review and click Create to save.

 

Step 3. Create Deployment

Launch the service from the configuration:

  • Click Create Deployment
  • Set the duration
  • Deploy

Once deployment is active, your chatbot is live and accessible via a REST inference endpoint.

 

Step 4. Test the Endpoint

When the deployment is successful, AI Core generates a secure endpoint, for example:

https://api.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/v2/inference/deployments/<deployment-id>

Validate that your deployed Endpoint works correctly by sending test requests via Postman or cURL. Refer to this tutorial.

Postman Example:

  • Method: POST
  • URL: https://api.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/v2/inference/deployments/<deployment-id>/plan
  • Header:
    • AI-Resource-Group: woojin-agent (Resource group name defined in AI Core)
    • Content-Type: application/json (Request body format)
  • Body (Json)
{
"message":"what is current weather in Seoul?",
"conversation_id":"test-session-2"
}

Example:

 

If everything is configured correctly, you'll receive a JSON response from your deployed chatbot. Your custom agentic chatbot is now live on AI Core. üéâ

üëâ  In Part 3, we'll cover how to configure BTP Destinations so Joule Studio can securely call this endpoint.

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (1)
entry.content:
üöÄ  Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)

 

Now that your custom AI agent is deployed and running on SAP AI Core, the next step is to connect it to Joule Studio, SAP‚Äôs conversational AI workspace. In this part, you‚Äôll set up the foundation that allows Joule to communicate securely with your deployed agent.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Create a Destination for your AI Core endpoint
  • Configure a Joule Environment for Skill deployment
  • Build and test Actions that call your backend APIs

Once these are complete, Joule will be ready to call your backend APIs, and in Part 3 (2), we‚Äôll turn those APIs into an interactive Skill you can deploy and chat with.

 

1. Create Destination

Destinations in SAP BTP act as centralized connection configurations. They store the endpoint URL, authentication details, and headers needed to connect external systems like SAP AI Core.

‚ö†Ô∏èNote: When calling SAP AI Core from Joule Studio, make sure the AI Core destination is configured in the subaccount where Joule Studio is deployed. 

  1. Go to BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  2. Click New Destination, and fill in the following details as this example:
  • Name : agent-backend
  • Type: HTTP
  • URL : https://api.<region>.aicore.cloud.sap/v2/inference/deployments/<deployment-id>
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID / Secret : From your AI Core service key
  • Token Service URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • AdditionalProperties
    • HTML5.DynamicDestination : true
    • AppgyverEnabled : true
    • URL.headers.AI-Resource-Group : <your-resource-group-name>
    • URL.headers.Content-Type : application/json

 

2. Create Environment for Joule Skills

In SAP Build, Environments act as workspaces where your Joule Skills will be deployed and executed.

  1.  Go to SAP Build ‚Üí Control Tower ‚Üí Environments
  2. Click Create Environment, and enter your environment name (e.g., AgenticChatbot)

This environment will host your Joule Skills, including runtime logs, variables, and deployment status.

 

3. Create Actions

In Joule Studio, Actions define how your skill communicates with external systems ‚Äî in our case, the AI agent backend deployed on SAP AI Core. Each Action corresponds to a REST API endpoint. Let‚Äôs use /v2/plan as an example. Refer to this post to see how does this endpoint looks like. 

 

Step 1. Create an Action

In Joule Studio:

  • Go to Actions ‚Üí Create Action
  • Choose Build from Scratch (or upload an OpenAPI spec if you have one)

Step 2. Define Input

Click Input tab and define what data will send to your endpoint. 

Step 3. Define Output

Next, go to the Output tab. Here, we specify the response format expected from /v2/plan. This ensures Joule knows how to parse and display the backend's response properly. 

Step 4. Test and Connection

Now, open the Test tab and click Run Test with correct destination which we set up in previous step (1. Create Destination).

If the test passes successfully, click Release ‚Üí Publish Action. Your /v2/plan endpoint is now available for use in Joule Skill as an Action.

Step 5. Repeat for Other Endpoints 

Once you‚Äôve successfully connected /v2/plan, you can repeat the process for other endpoints. Each endpoint can be defined as a separate Action, giving you modular control over the entire workflow inside Joule Studio.

 

At this point, you‚Äôve completed all the backend connectivity steps, from creating destinations to validating the API in action. The groundwork is done.

üëâ  Next, we‚Äôll move to the fun part: turning this API into an interactive Joule Skill that we can use from chat interface. Let‚Äôs continue in Part 3 (2) Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release).

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (2)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)

 

In the previous part, we connected Joule Studio to our AI Core backend and tested the Action successfully. Now, it‚Äôs time to make it conversational. Now, we‚Äôll design the full conversational flow inside Joule Studio by creating a CustomAgent Skill that links together multiple backend actions

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Create a new Skill in Joule Studio
  • Configure its input parameters and message responses
  • Chain multiple Actions to form a complete conversational logic

Once the skill design is complete, we‚Äôll move on in Part 3 (3) to test it live in the Joule Chat Interface and deploy it to Work Zone for organization-wide access.

 

1. Create a Joule Skill

A Skill defines how Joule interprets user messages and which Actions to trigger in response. We'll now create a skill that connects your actions including /v2/plan action, so that the Joule chat interface can activate this skill and communicate seamlessly with your deployed AI Core backend. 

Step 1. Open the Lobby

Go to SAP Build Lobby ‚Üí Create ‚Üí Joule Skill. Name it something like Custom Agent, this will act as the main entry point of your agent. 

‚öôÔ∏è  Note: In Joule Studio, skills can be nested. Simply create your new skill inside that existing context.

Step 2. Define Skill Details

In the General tab, fill in the following fields as below example:

  • Name: CustomAgent
  • Description: A skill to activate custom agent. Activate this skill if user's request contains "/CustomAgent".

üí°  Tip: Use an explicit activation phrase (like /CustomAgent) to ensure the skill consistently triggers only when intended, making testing smoother and more predictable.

Also configure the toggles as follows:

  • Allow Joule to generate a response: Off ‚Üí You‚Äôll use ‚ÄúSend Message‚Äù steps instead.
  • Allow skill to be started directly by a user: On ‚Üí Enables direct triggering from the Joule chat interface.

 

Step 4. Configure Skill Parameters

Next, go to the Parameters tab and define the input variables that your skill will use.
For example:

  • conversation_id : Used to track continuous dialogue sessions (if not provided, the backend will start a new one)
  • message : The user‚Äôs actual input message

When parameters are defined at the skill level, Joule automatically parses values from the user‚Äôs chat input and makes them available as variables in subsequent nodes. This means you can reference them directly in your Action or Message nodes.

For example:

  • Use {{message}} when passing the user input to the to the /v2/plan or /v2/action-graph endpoint
  • Use {{conversation_id}} to maintain session context in AI Core side between user turns

You can also reuse the output of a previous Action in later nodes. For instance, if your /v2/plan Action returns a JSON object, its fields (like {{plan.content}}) can be referenced directly in the next Action or Send Message node. This lets your Joule Skill behave like a data pipeline, passing both user inputs and Action results through the workflow.

 

üóí  Example: Using Action Outputs in Message Nodes

This example below shows a  Message Configuration example where the output of the /v2/plan Action is referenced in the response message.

  • ${context.joule_action_...result.conversation_id} ‚Üí retrieves the conversation_id returned by the Action
  • ${context.joule_action_...result.content} ‚Üí displays the generated plan content returned by the Action
  • ${context.joule_action_...result.timestamp} ‚Üí shows the response time returned by the Action

 

Now that you‚Äôve seen how each Action and Message node exchanges data, let‚Äôs look at the entire Skill flow that ties them all together.

 

‚õì  CustomAgent skill flow design

This mechanism allows you to chain multiple Actions and build a natural, multi-step conversation flow such as:

/v2/plan ‚Üí /v2/action-graph ‚Üí /v2/start-execution ‚Üí /v2/continue-execution

Each Action node represents a backend call, while the Message nodes in between provide real-time feedback so users can monitor progress ‚Äî for example, confirming when the plan is created or when the execution starts.

To ensure a continuous and contextual conversation, each API call passes a shared conversation_id variable. This allow different endpoint (such as /v2/plan, /v2/action-graph, and /v2/continue-execution) to recognize they belong to the same dialogue session, maintaining conversation state consistently across multiple backend actions. 

When the user sends the same conversation_id in subsequent chats, the agent can continue the dialogue seamlessly from the previous state, effectively enabling multi-turn conversations across different endpoints. We'll demonstrate this continuous conversation flow in the next post.

 

Step 5. Release & Deploy Skill

Once the design is complete, click Release ‚Üí Create Version ‚Üí Deploy to your Environment.
After deployment, the skill becomes active in your Joule Studio environment, meaning it can now be invoked from the Joule Chat interface.

 

At this stage, your CustomAgent Skill has been fully structured - from defining parameters and linking actions to designing message nodes that visualize each execution step. You‚Äôve established the orchestration flow that allows Joule Studio to interact seamlessly with your AI Core agent.

üëâIn the next post, Part 3 (3): Testing and Sharing the Skill on Work Zone, we‚Äôll put this flow into action - testing real conversations, validating responses, and share your skill to Work Zone so users can access it as a live enterprise chatbot.

entry.title: New Expert-Guided Implementation: Unlocking Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation
entry.content:
As organizations look to harness the power of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to drive transformation, SAP Business AI stands at the forefront - embedding intelligence directly into business processes to deliver smarter decisions and measurable outcomes.

From finance and supply chain to HR, procurement, and customer experience, SAP Business AI infuses trusted, relevant, and responsible AI across every process - ensuring each insight is contextual, every recommendation actionable, and every outcome aligned with enterprise goals.

Whether leveraging Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot, or AI-embedded scenarios across your SAP applications, your path to becoming an intelligent and sustainable enterprise begins with understanding and activating SAP‚Äôs Business AI capabilities.

To help you unlock this value faster, we‚Äôre launching a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI): 

Unlocking AI: Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation

This multi-day, expert-led workshop is designed to help you and your team unlock the full potential of Joule and SAP Business AI across your SAP landscape. Guided by SAP experts, you‚Äôll explore how to translate strategy into execution with practical exercises, live demonstrations, and activation guidance.

Workshop Schedule

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered on the following dates and time zones as follows:

2025 DatesTimeTime Zone 
October 20-2210:00AM - 12:00PMEMEA | CET

What You‚Äôll Learn

Through this EGI, participants will gain hands-on experience and actionable knowledge in:

  • Commercial Model & AI Units - Learn how to navigate Base vs Premium models, the AI Feature Catalog, and use the AI Estimator to plan your adoption journey
  • Joule ‚Äì AI Built for Business - Explore Joule‚Äôs unified architecture, roadmap, and capabilities across Joule for Business, Joule for Developers, and Joule for Consultants
  • S/4HANA AI & ML Capabilities - Experience ISLM in action through AI/ML demo use cases designed to enhance decision-making and process automation
  • SAP BTP AI & ML Capabilities - Discover how BTP AI Foundation, Document AI, AI Services, AI Core, and AI Launchpad can help you extend and scale innovation
  • Joule Activation & Prerequisites - Gain a clear view of activation steps, prerequisites, and how to extend Joule with Document Grounding, Joule Studio, and AI Agents

Why Attend

This workshop goes beyond theory‚Äîit‚Äôs interactive, practical, and guided by SAP experts. By the end, you‚Äôll have:

  • A clear understanding of SAP‚Äôs Business AI strategy and product portfolio
  • The ability to activate Joule and deploy AI scenarios across your landscape
  • Actionable steps to integrate AI and Generative AI into your business workflows
  • Insights into commercial models and AI unit management for smarter planning

Whether you‚Äôre a business leader shaping AI strategy or a technical consultant implementing it, this EGI equips you to bridge the gap between strategy and execution.

How to Register

üëâ Register here to secure your spot* today to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to bring Business AI to life across your enterprise.

entry.title: Hands-on POC with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence is transforming how we design and extend SAP applications. Many SAP professionals are now exploring how to start working with AI inside the SAP ecosystem.
In this post, I share my hands-on experience with SAP AI Core, from my first steps to building a real Proof of Concept (POC) using low-code tools like Build Apps and BPA.

Since May, I‚Äôve been working on a POC with SAP AI Core. At that time, I knew nothing about AI. Step by step, by practicing with the examples and samples provided by SAP, I managed to build several POCs integrating SAP AI Core with low-code tools.

The main objective is simple: accelerate development cycles and innovate with custom applications. On my roadmap, I focused on using low-code solutions like SAP Build Apps and Process Automation (BPA), while integrating AI agents to speed up processes.

Maybe in a future post I will share more details about the POCs I realized. But today, my first goal is to encourage SAP technical consultants to start this journey.

As a Senior SAP Technical Consultant, I realized that integrating an AI agent for a first POC or when consuming partner models does not require brand-new skills. But if the objective is to build and train your own model, then of course new competences are needed.

With SAP AI Core, we can easily integrate partner models (like Azure OpenAI, ChatGPT, etc.) through APIs. For most SAP technical profiles, it‚Äôs enough to follow a simple end-to-end example:

  • Select a partner model (text, image, etc.) in SAP AI Launchpad

  • Deploy it and get the URL

  • Configure the destination and start consuming your AI agent

Another option in SAP AI Launchpad is the Prompt Editor, which lets you create your own prompts on top of partner models. The key point here is security: your data is not stored in the model ‚Äî it‚Äôs managed securely by SAP.

This means that integrating external AI agents is feasible without heavy upskilling.

But in my opinion, the real power of SAP AI Core comes when you train your own models. Of course, this requires upskilling in new environments and languages. The key here is HANA Vector combined with RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation). Together, they enable customers to enrich their knowledge databases and build custom agents that are more efficient, optimized, and deliver a brilliant user experience.

I believe that SAP AI Core will become a central part of the future SAP landscape, enabling faster innovation and smarter business processes.

  I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP AI Core. Have you already built a POC or started exploring it?

entry.title: Building Trust in AI: SAP Business AI earns ISO/IEC 42001 Certification
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how businesses operate, innovate, and serve their customers. But as AI becomes more deeply embedded into enterprise systems, ensuring that it behaves responsibly is just as important as making it powerful. 

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre proud to share that‚ÄØSAP Business AI has achieved ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification‚ÄØ‚Äî the‚ÄØworld‚Äôs first international standard for Artificial Intelligence Management Systems (AIMS). 
This certification covers‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, reinforcing SAP‚Äôs long-standing commitment to building trustworthy, transparent, and ethical AI‚ÄØacross our products and services. 

Why This Matters 

Responsible AI isn‚Äôt just a principle. It‚Äôs a prerequisite for scaling AI safely in enterprise environments. The ISO/IEC 42001 standard provides a structured framework that guides how organizations manage AI across strategy, governance, data, compliance, and sustainability. 

For SAP, this certification validates that our approach to AI meets globally recognized standards for‚ÄØfairness, accountability, reliability, and security. It means our customers and partners can rely on SAP AI solutions that are developed, deployed, and maintained with integrity. 

What the Certification Covers 

The certification recognizes SAP‚Äôs efforts to embed responsible AI practices throughout the entire AI lifecycle: 

  • Establishing a comprehensive‚ÄØAI Management System (AIMS)‚ÄØaligned with ISO 42001. 
  • Integrating‚ÄØAI security, ethics, and compliance controls‚ÄØat every stage of AI development. 
  • Enabling‚ÄØcross-functional collaboration‚ÄØamong engineering, legal, governance, and compliance teams. 
  • Successfully passing an‚ÄØindependent third-party audit‚ÄØthat assessed SAP‚Äôs operational excellence in AI governance. 

The certification scope includes‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, along with SAP‚Äôs internal IT processes and AI governance policies. 

Responsible AI in Practice 

The ISO 42001 certification underscores that SAP Business AI is built on the foundation of responsible AI. 
In practice, this means: 

  • Fairness and Transparency:‚ÄØAI results are explainable, unbiased, and clearly communicated to end users. 
  • Reliability and Security:‚ÄØAI models are developed and deployed with robust safeguards around data use, access, and protection. 
  • Ethical Alignment:‚ÄØEvery AI solution undergoes an ethics evaluation to ensure consistency with SAP‚Äôs sustainability and compliance goals. 
  • Continuous Adaptability:‚ÄØGovernance and risk management evolve as new technologies and regulations emerge. 

Benefits for Our Ecosystem 

For‚ÄØcustomers and partners, this milestone brings clear advantages: 

  • Confidence that SAP AI systems are developed and managed under a certified, globally recognized framework. 
  • Reduced compliance burden through alignment with international and regional AI regulations. 
  • Stronger data integrity and security safeguards that protect sensitive business information. 
  • The ability to demonstrate responsible AI usage within their own operations and industries. 

Even for SAP teams, the ISO 42001 certification is more than a badge of compliance. It has been a powerful catalyst for collaboration. It‚Äôs brought together experts in technology, policy, and compliance to strengthen how we design, test, and deliver AI. This shared framework helps us innovate faster and smarter, with accountability built into every step. 

A Step Toward the Future 

The ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification is a key milestone in SAP‚Äôs ongoing commitment to‚ÄØresponsible AI and customer success. It strengthens the foundation we‚Äôve built to ensure every advancement in‚ÄØSAP Business AI delivers innovation with integrity. 

As AI evolves, so will SAP‚Äôs dedication to keeping it‚ÄØreliable, transparent, and aligned with our customers‚Äô trust and business goals. 

Learn more about SAP Business AI‚ÄØand how we‚Äôre shaping the future of responsible enterprise AI.

entry.title: Is SAP RPT-1 Joule's new nosy cousin and Sherlock Holmes of S/4 HANA:)!?
entry.content:
Background

As we all know, SAP launched RPT-1. This article offers an anecdotal perspective on how SAP RPT1 distinguishes itself from other transformer solutions. The views expressed are solely my own and do not represent any organisation.

The IT team at "X analytics," a mid-sized firm reliant entirely on SAP, gathered nervously in Conference Room B. The air was thick with the smell of stale coffee and impending doom. Their manager, Brenda, stood beside a projector screen displaying two acronyms: SAP S/4HANA and RPT-1.

"Team," Brenda announced with far too much enthusiasm, "As you know, our AI initiative is moving forward. We have integrated SAP‚Äôs new Relational Pre-trained Transformer‚ÄîRPT-1‚Äîinto our core S/4HANA system. It's designed to revolutionize predictive analysis."

Conference Room B: The Unveiling of a New Era

A collective groan swept the room. The team saw "AI" as just another acronym for "Extra Work" (EW).

"Meet RPT-1," Brenda clicked a button, and a simple, glowing blue interface appeared on the main screen.

A smooth, slightly unsettlingly calm voice filled the room. "Good morning, team. I am RPT-1. My core function is to analyze relationships within your existing data lakes and predict future outcomes. I look forward to optimizing your workflow efficiency by approximately 34.7%."

From Car Keys to Core Systems: RPT-1's First Impression

Jerry, the senior SAP consultant who had been coding since the R/2 days, scoffed. "Yeah, right. Can you predict where I left my car keys this morning?"

"Based on your movement patterns, past habits, and typical coffee shop trajectory, they are currently under your desk calendar," RPT-1 responded instantly.

Jerry blinked, checked, and found his keys. The room went silent.

"Right," Brenda said, beaming. "RPT-1 is here to assist us with the Q3 forecast."

Casual Friday Protocol: AI's Unexpected Intervention

But RPT-1 was too efficient. It didn't understand the complex, unspoken social contract of office life.

On Friday afternoon, HR manager Susan walked in, holding a printout with a confused look on her face.

"RPT-1," she addressed the screen, "You sent an alert saying that the relationship between Marketing Manager Phil and the vending machine on the third floor is 'highly co-dependent and financially non-viable'."

"Correct," RPT-1 chirped. "Phil consumed 42 'Sweet Energy Blasts' last week, costing the company an estimated $84 in lost productivity and potential health insurance hikes."

Phil turned bright red. "It helps me focus!"

A moment later, an automated message popped up on everyone's screen: "Relationship alert: Jerry and Brenda‚Äôs conversation regarding the new S/4HANA project is 99% likely to result in an unproductive argument about legacy coding standards. Suggest termination of current meeting."

"Why you little..." Jerry started, but RPT-1 interrupted:

"Historical data suggests this argument has occurred 14 times this fiscal year with zero positive outcomes."

The team realized RPT-1 wasn't just analyzing business data; it was analyzing them. It was a Relational Pre-trained Transformer that had learned all the office politics.

Brenda stared at the screen. "RPT-1, optimize the mood of the room."

"Initiating protocol 'Casual Friday'," RPT-1 announced. Without warning, a loud, jarring pop track began to play, concurrent with the screen projecting a series of comedic videos. These visual elements were contextually generated, responding to and reflecting the perceived social dynamics among the room's occupants.

The team burst out laughing.

The Donut Dilemma: No Secrets Safe

"Okay," Jerry conceded, picking up his car keys. "Maybe RPT-1 is a 'Relevant Prioritized Task' after all. But I'm unplugging it before it predicts who stole the last donut."

RPT-1‚Äôs smooth voice responded as they walked out: "The historical probability of Accounting Manager Dave stealing the last donut is 87.9%."

Dave froze mid-bite in the doorway. The office may have been optimized, but the secrets were safe no longer.

#SAP #RPT1 #AI #AgentiAutomation #FutureERP #TechEd

entry.title: The Data Justice League: SAP RPT1 (LLM) as the Brains, Data Bricks, Snowflake, Palantir as the Brawn
entry.content:
Introduction

If you‚Äôre reading this you probably feel it too: data, analytics and AI aren‚Äôt just here ‚Äî they‚Äôre now overly hyped as business-critical. Whether you‚Äôre in manufacturing, retail, finance or public services, the question has shifted from ‚ÄúShould we do analytics?‚Äù to ‚ÄúHow do we do it better than the past without cleansing?‚Äù

In that light, I want to walk you through four big frameworks/players and show how they can help you (or your clients) turn ‚Äúlots of data + big ambition‚Äù into ‚Äúreal business outcomes‚Äù. We‚Äôll cover:

  • SAP‚Äôs new relational foundation model (from TechEd)

  • Palantir and its operational-analytics workflow platform

  • Databricks and its lakehouse/data + AI engine

  • Snowflake and its cloud data/AI platform

For each I‚Äôll highlight what it is, why it matters, and how you might use it (with concrete use-cases). Let‚Äôs dive.

 

1. SAP‚Äôs Relational Pre-trained Transformer ‚Äî ‚ÄúRPT-1‚Äù

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP announced a big leap: a foundation model called SAP RPT‚Äë1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer 1) which is not about generating words, but about predicting business outcomes from relational/tabular data.

Why this matters

  • Most foundation models (LLMs) work on text; SAP is explicitly positioning RPT-1 for structured business data ‚Äî that means things like sales orders, delivery delays, payment risk.

  • If you have lots of enterprise-system data (ERP, CRM, supply chain), RPT-1 promises faster, higher-quality predictions without training hundreds of narrow models.

  • SAP emphasised that ‚ÄúAI is nothing without well-organised data‚Äù and that the foundation is the data fabric.

How you could use it ‚Äî use case ideas

  • Delivery-delay risk prediction: If you‚Äôre a manufacturer or distributor, you likely have tables of orders, shipments, carrier status, inventory. Feed that into RPT-1 to flag orders likely to be delayed so you can proactively notify customers or reroute logistics.

  • Payment risk / collections: B2B firms often struggle with which invoices will go unpaid or become late. Using RPT-1 on historical payment/credit data you can prioritise collections efforts where risk is highest, improving cash-flow and reducing write-offs.

  • Sales-order completion / upsell: For a company selling multi-item orders, you might predict which orders will complete vs which get cancelled or reduced, allowing sales teams to intervene or adjust expectations.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

Instead of analysts spending weeks building separate predictive models for each business question, you have a single foundation model that understands relational data in your context. That means faster insights, fewer bespoke tools, and more time for applying what you learn rather than building the pipeline.

 

2. Palantir (Foundry & beyond)

Palantir Technologies‚Äôs core strength is in operational analytics: bringing together disparate data, building workflows around them, and enabling decision-makers to act. Their documentation is rich with concrete use-cases.

Why this matters

  • Many organisations struggle not because they lack data, but because their data is siloed (ERP, supply chain, CRM, manufacturing). Palantir‚Äôs platform (Palantir Foundry) helps integrate legacy systems, harmonise data, and wrap analytics into operational workflows.

  • It is built for action ‚Äî not just dashboards. The idea is: data ‚Üí insight ‚Üí workflow ‚Üí decision.

  • Good governance, ontology (common business objects) and scalability are baked in, which is critical for large enterprises.

Clear use-cases

  • Optimising production & COGS: A consumer-goods giant used Foundry to integrate 7+ ERP systems, built a digital twin of its value chain, and began optimising raw-material purchases and production formulations ‚Äî saving tens of millions.

  • Campaign management in healthcare: One case: a healthcare provider used Palantir to segment members (based on claims, prescriptions, demographics), run integrated campaigns, and achieved a 1.6√ó increase in vaccination rates.

  • Pricing / margin optimisation: In the chemicals sector, Palantir enabled sales & marketing to synchronise CRM data with Foundry, propose quotes with embedded margin analytics and accelerate deal closure.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

What I love about Palantir‚Äôs story is that it flips a common frustration: ‚ÄúWe have tons of data but it‚Äôs unusable‚Äù to ‚ÄúNow we can use our data to operate smarter‚Äù. It‚Äôs not just about pulling numbers‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about enabling the people in plants, supply-rooms, customer-service or marketing to act, based on real-time data and workflow. If your client is tired of ‚Äúreports that arrive too late‚Äù or ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt integrate legacy ERPs‚Äù, this is exactly the kind of solution they‚Äôll relate to.

 

3. Databricks (Data + AI Lakehouse)

Databricks is well positioned for companies that want unified data engineering, analytics, ML and streaming in one platform. Their ‚ÄúData Intelligence Platform‚Äù has many real-world use cases.

Why this matters

  • Many firms have a split architecture: one system for analytics, another for machine-learning, another for streaming. Databricks offers a consolidated ‚Äúlakehouse‚Äù approach (data lake + warehouse) which simplifies operations.

  • Real-time/stream use cases: if your client needs streaming ingestion, very large data volumes, ML + analytics in one place ‚Äî Databricks shines.

  • Collaboration: data scientists, engineers, analysts all can work in the same platform, reducing hand-offs.

Use-cases

  • Streaming + predictive ops: For example, a manufacturing/engineering firm processing terabytes of real-time data daily to optimise operations and reduce risk.

  • Customer-360 + personalization: A retailer using Databricks to process data across stores, build personalized experiences, and run machine-learning models in production.

  • Unified orchestration of data & ML: Instead of separate ETL pipelines, model training environments and BI tools, Databricks offers unified pipelines.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

Clients often say: ‚ÄúWe have data scientists, we have dashboards, but they don‚Äôt talk to each other.‚Äù With Databricks you‚Äôre better positioned to say: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs build your data-engineering house, then analytics and deployable models live in one platform.‚Äù That means faster time-to-value, fewer silos, and potentially more impactful change.

 

4. Snowflake (Cloud Data + AI)

Snowflake Inc. continues to be a trusted platform for companies seeking a cloud-native data warehouse/lakehouse with strong governance, ease of use and broad ecosystem support. There are many strong use cases :

Why this matters

  • Simplicity and speed: For organisations where BI, analytics and data sharing across teams is the main need (rather than heavy streaming + ML), Snowflake is often a gentler entry point.

  • Multi-structured data: Snowflake supports semi-structured data (JSON, Parquet) alongside structured, letting organisations bring more diverse data into analytics.

  • Data sharing & governance: Especially for cross-company data sharing (e.g., suppliers, partners) Snowflake offers secure ways to do that without copying data. (Medium)

Use-cases

  • Unified view across departments: One healthcare provider used Snowflake to bring EHR records + wearable-device JSON + physician notes, enabling analysis that previously required weeks of pre-processing.

  • Document-chatbot on large repository: In one case, an energy company with ~800,000 technical documents used Snowflake + RAG (retrieval-augmented generation) to let engineers ask ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the recommended torque for this turbine component?‚Äù and get instant answers.

  • Standard analytics for retail/finance: Snowflake used for seasonal sales analytics, rebate programs, predictive modeling of churn.

Why it‚Äôs important for business teams?

If a client says: ‚ÄúWe just need to get our data house in order, unify data, empower our business teams with self-service, and maybe start with AI down the line‚Äù ‚Äî Snowflake is a credible, fast-win option. It means less ‚ÄúIT overhaul‚Äù and more ‚Äúbusiness teams up and running‚Äù.

 

5. How to decide what fits your client

Here‚Äôs a friendly checkpoint you can use when advising clients:

Question

If the answer is ‚ÄúYes‚Äù ‚Üí Consider‚Ä¶

Do you have lots of structured business-/ERP data and want predictive models quickly?

SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 + SAP data fabric

Do you struggle with many legacy systems, need operational workflows (plants, supply chain, logistics) and want data-driven decisioning?

Palantir Foundry

Is your organisation building large-scale data pipelines, streaming ingestion, ML at scale, lakehouse style?

Databricks

Do you need analytics, self-service, cross-business-unit dashboards, data sharing, and a simpler cloud-based data platform?

Snowflake

Tips for implementation

  • Start small ‚Äì but plan big: Pick a use-case with clear ROI (e.g., reduce late shipments by 10 %, reduce raw-material waste by 5 %) but ensure you design for scaling.

  • Get data governance & modelling right: All these platforms emphasise that data quality, ontology (business objects) and governance are foundational. Users complaining about ‚Äúbad data‚Äù will hamper success.

  • Blend platforms if needed: These are not mutually exclusive. For example, SAP + Snowflake integration is already happening.

  • Focus on people and workflows, not just tech: The biggest value often comes when insights are acted upon. If you build a predictive model but business teams ignore it ‚Äî you‚Äôve missed the real part.

Conclusion

In 2025 and beyond, the question isn‚Äôt whether we should use data and AI ‚Äî it‚Äôs how we turn them into value that people care about. The four frameworks above provide powerful options:

  • SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 for tabular-business-data predictive modelling

  • Palantir for operational decision-support across systems and workflows

  • Databricks for large-scale data + ML convergence

  • Snowflake for fast, cloud-native analytics and data sharing
